caption.p: List of candidate medicinal plants traditionally used for cancer treatment in the study areas.

tr.td: Justicia schimperiana (Hochst. ex Nees) T. Anderson
Fresh roots are crashed and boiled, and the cool decoction is drunk before meal
Justicia schimperiana (Hochst. ex Nees) T. Anderson
Fresh leaves are pounded, and the juice is applied on the affected area
Fresh roots are crashed, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Leaves are roasted on metal plate, pounded into powder, mixed with animal butter, and smeared on the affected part
Young leaves are crashed, and the sap sniffed
Young leaves are crashed and applied on the affected area
Young leaves are crashed and applied
Leaves are crashed and infused in cold water overnight and drunk before meal and applied on the affected area
Fresh roots are crashed, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh roots are crashed, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Stems are cut, and the sap is applied
Dry roots are pounded, and the powder is mixed with honey
Young leaves are chewed by the healer and spit on
Fresh leaves are crashed and infused in cold water
Dried leaves are ground and macerated in coffee or tea
Dried leaves are ground and macerated in coffee or tea
Dried leaves will be ground and decocted in hot water
Fresh leaves are pounded, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves are pounded, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves are pounded and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves are pounded, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves are chewed by the healer and spit on
Fresh leaves are pounded, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh roots are pounded, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves are roasted for 2 minutes and applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves or succulent stems are crashed, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Dry bark is pounded, and the powder is applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves are crashed, macerated in cold water, and drunk
Fresh roots are pounded, and the sap is applied on the affected area
The mixture of fresh leaves of Albizia schimperiana and Carissa spinarum is macerated in cold water for 2 days, and the macerated liquid is drunk
Dry leaves or seeds are ground, macerated in cold water, and drunk
Dry seeds are ground, mixed with honey, and applied
Fresh leaves are crashed, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves are crashed, macerated, and drunk
Fresh leaves are crushed, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Fresh leaves are crashed, macerated overnight, and drunk
Fresh roots are crushed, boiled, and drunk
Fresh leaves are crushed, and the sap is applied on the affected area
Dry plant parts are ground, mixed with honey, and applied
Dry leaves are decocted and drunk
Sida schimperiana Hochst. ex A. Rich.
Fresh leaves and roots are crashed, macerated, and drunk
Dry bark is ground, macerated, and drunk before meal
Dry roots are ground, mixed with water and honey, and drunk, or dry roots are ground, mixed with honey, and applied on the affected area
Dry leaves and roots of Syzygium guineense and dry leaves of Osyris quadripartita are ground, mixed, decocted, and drunk
Fresh leaves and roots are crashed and applied with a bandage
Dry roots are ground, macerated, and drunk
Dry roots are ground and taken with food
Fresh bark is crashed and squeezed, and the sap is applied
Fresh roots of Dorstenia barnimiana mixed with fresh leaves of Clematis simensis, pounded, and applied
Dry bark is ground, decocted, and drunk
Dry leaves are ground, mixed with honey, and eaten
Dry leaves are ground, decocted, and drunk
Dry roots are ground, mixed with honey, and applied or dry roots are ground, decocted, and drunk
Dry leaves are ground, pasted with cold water, and applied
Fresh leaves are crashed and applied
Dry roots are ground, mixed with honey, and eaten
Fresh leaves are ground, macerated in cold spring water, and drunk
Dry leaves are ground, macerated in cold water, and drunk
Dry roots are ground, pasted with honey and eaten, and applied

fn.p: UV = use value; RFC = relative frequency of citation; CI = cultural importance index.
